text:
I do this for two clients and even as the lead for both its done very differently in each company. 
Client 1- strategy is created with everyone on the team (6 people) including product marketers, head of marketing, communications, SEO/website, and design. 
We all work closely to ensure progress is being made. There's no real calendar to speak of. (It's a startup, with typical startup characteristics). 

Client 2: I created the strategy with the director of communications, using current events, product launches, and timely industry stuff to make up the bulk of it. 
I manage the writers (4) deadlines, briefs, editing, and publishing, and the calendar.

Client 1- strategy is created with everyone on the team (6 people) including product marketers, head of marketing, communications, SEO/website, and design. 
We all work closely to ensure progress is being made. There's no real calendar to speak of. (It's a startup, with typical startup characteristics). 

Client 2: I created the strategy with the director of communications, using current events, product launches, and timely industry stuff to make up the bulk of it. 
I manage the writers (4) deadlines, briefs, editing, and publishing, and the calendar.

text:
As the Content Marketing Manager for my mid-size marketing team, I drive, create, and manage our editorial calendar. I set up an annual meeting with marketing leadership (CMO, Director of Demand Gen, Director of Branding) to understand business objectives for the next year and start brainstorming brand "themes" and taglines for quarterly campaigns to further the company's business objectives. After that meeting(s), I inform our 2 freelance writers of the themes and ask them for any ideas or feedback as I finalize the high-level editorial calendar for the year.

I hold weekly, monthly, and quarterly meetings where we review the editorial calendar together throughout the rest of the year and make adjustments as needed with the appropriate team members. Our writers attend the weeklys, but the monthly and quarterly meetings are more strategic, so they don't attend those.
